description: From English dialectal slat (“to throw or dash about”), from Middle English sclatten, skleatten (“to flap”), from Old English slǣtan (“to sleat, slate”) and/or Old Norse sletta (“to slap, dash”)  +‎ -er.

verbs.description: slatter (third-person singular simple present slatters, present participle slattering, simple past and past participle slattered) (intransitive)

entries.meaning: To be awkward, careless, or negligent, especially with regard to dress and neatness.
